title: PUBLIC LIVES; Only the Party Is Minor, Not Its Councilwoman

body: AS the New York City housing market flourished in much of the period between 1999 and 2002, the pace of apartment deregulation quickened in the most desirable neighborhoods of Manhattan and market rents rose sharply in much of the city, especially in Brooklyn and Queens, where median rents exceed $1,000 for the first time in some neighborhoods.
title: As Rents Rise, So Does Deregulation

body: Ten years. To Jose Lopez, 58, it has all been a blur. It isn't that the time has sped by. It is that he has lumbered through it, weighed down by grief over the death of his son and namesake. title: The Neediest Cases; A Father Emerges From Grief to Fight Cancer

body: Two days after his loss to a third-party candidate for City Council, Geoffrey A. Davis appeared at City Hall yesterday to concede to his opponent, Letitia James, and to explain his candidacy as therapy in dealing with the murder of his brother, Councilman James E. Davis. Mr. Davis was the Democratic candidate in an emotional race to succeed his
title: Slain Councilman's Brother Concedes and Looks Ahead

body: The brother of a murdered councilman saw the Brooklyn seat slip away yesterday in an election that brought large victories for incumbents across New York City. It was a crushing moment for Geoffrey A. Davis, who had made it clear that he wanted to carry on the work of his brother, Councilman James E. Davis, who was shot to death in City Hall in
title: THE 2003 ELECTION: CITY COUNCIL; Letitia James Wins Seat That Slain Man's Brother Felt Was Rightfully His

body: New York City voters overwhelmingly rejected a measure yesterday that would have instituted nonpartisan city elections, voting to forgo changes in a system of selecting municipal officials that has been in place for nearly a century. It was a stinging defeat for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who had invested millions of his own fortune in a campaign
title: THE 2003 ELECTION: CITY CHARTER; CITY VOTES DOWN AN EFFORT TO END PARTY PRIMARIES

body: Today is Election Day. All the contests are local, so the results will affect everyday lives -- from trash removal and taxes to safe streets, good schools and clean government. title: Choices for Election Day

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; On This Ordinary Block in Brooklyn, The Kurds Are Always in the News

title: Carrying a Brother's Torch, Shakily; Davis in Tough Race to Win Council Seat Vacated by Murder

body: By the time darkness descended on New York on Thursday evening, I was eating a pizza with a friend on my stoop in Park Slope, Brooklyn. We wanted to hear the end of the Yankee game, so we got into my car and started driving. Pretty soon we'd picked up five middle-aged Russian women who had been walking from Midtown Manhattan to Brighton Beach.
title: The New York That's Visible in the Dark

body: Grief for Slain Daughter, Worse in Spring, Persists The passage of time has softened his grief, Lawrence Watkins says, but all that means is that the ''crying and more emotional outbreaks'' have diminished. body: To the Editor: Let me add one more sign to Bruce McCall's witty parody ''The Bleepin' Rules of the Road'': No Pedestrians on Sidewalk -- Parking for City Vehicles Only. It wouldn't be an exaggeration. Unfortunately, many New Yorkers who live near police stations or fire houses will recognize this sign as a sorry statement of fact. Paul Sheridan
title: Sign Language

body: The police said yesterday that they had arrested a man wanted in a series of robberies at day care centers, churches, medical offices and small businesses in Brooklyn over the past two months. The suspect, Ronald Fredericks, 31, was arrested on Malcolm X Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant shortly after a call came in on the Crimestoppers tip line
title: Man Is Charged in Robberies At Churches and Businesses

body: The police said yesterday that they are linking the man who robbed a Brooklyn priest at gunpoint on Thursday to 10 other holdups at day care centers, churches, offices and small businesses in Brooklyn since Dec. 20. The man approaches victims by asking questions to get into a building. Once inside, he pulls out a silver pistol and demands money. In
title: Robber of Priest Is a Suspect In 11 Holdups In Brooklyn

body: A priest was robbed at gunpoint yesterday in the rectory of St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in Prospect Heights, the police said. About 11 a.m., a man who seemed to be in his 20's knocked on the door of the rectory, at 563 Sterling Place, and insisted on talking to a priest, the police said. The priest asked the man to come back later.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Priest Robbed At Church

body: Within less than two hours yesterday morning, two men were killed in separate shootings in Queens and Brooklyn, one at a bodega and the other at a deli. In a third shooting, an employee of a Brooklyn supermarket was shot to death last night by a fellow employe, the police said. John Freddy, 43, was shot at 7 a.m. at the Central Mini Market, at
title: 3 Killed in Separate Shootings In Stores in Brooklyn and Queens

body: THE dream of Albano Ballerini and Ellen Fishman to own a restaurant will come true on Friday. Aliseo will open in the storefront of the building they own and live in at 665 Vanderbilt Avenue (Park Place) in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The last four years of planning and construction may have been difficult, but simply by opening their doors, the
title: Rolling the Dice On a Family Dream

body: Deconstructivism is being put to a vote in Brooklyn. An elevator tower, below left, added to the former Daily News printing plant, at 535 Dean Street in Prospect Heights, doesn't sit well with some condominium owners in the building. The $500,000 tower by Elena Kalman, the project's architect, is clad in aluminum panels and craggy stucco. It
title: CURRENTS: CITY LANDSCAPE; An Elevator Tower Hangs in the Balance

body: Plagued by gloomy poll numbers and an intransigent economy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged in his State of the City address yesterday that his administration's decision to impose an 18.5 percent property tax increase had enraged many New Yorkers, and he expressed sympathy for those forced to sacrifice. Mr. Bloomberg laid out a modest
title: MAYOR OPTIMISTIC DESPITE CITY'S PAIN

body: To the Editor: A higher value than recycling, and even above reuse (as mulch), is reduction. Why not have a live pine tree in our home? We can appreciate its beauty, and benefit from its air-filtering abilities all year. No young trees need be cut down and transported to the city. No fire hazard from drying dead trees. And no need to recycle. Paul
title: Trees, Even Now, Can Be Recycled

author: E-mail: anemona@nytimes.com
body: ONE by one, the ghosts of Christmas past arrived at Prospect Park in Brooklyn last weekend. They traveled upright in collapsible shopping carts, tied to the tops of S.U.V.'s, dragged from the back of a Boy Scout troop's van and eerily wrapped like corpses in garbage bags and tablecloths. One, though only one, came bouncing up in a child's
title: COPING; Deep in the Piney Heart of the City
